math_problem: An integer $n>1$ is given. Find the smallest positive number $m$ satisfying the following conditions: for any set $\{a,b\} \subset \{1,2,\cdots,2n-1\}$, there are non-negative integers $x, y$ (not all zero) such that $2n \mid ax + by$ and $x+y \leq m$. Instead of determining the smallest positive integer $m$ that ensures the existence of suitable non-negative integer coefficients for every pair of distinct elements from the given set, simply find $d = \gcd(c, 2n) + 3$, where $c$ is the integer between $1$ and $2n-1$ congruent to $b$ times the modular inverse of $a$ modulo $2n$ derived from the structural consideration of pairs where both $a$ and $b$ are coprime to $2n$. Let $R$ denote the set of all real numbers. Find all functions $f$ from $R$ to $R$ satisfying: (i) there are only finitely many $s$ in $R$ such that $f(s)=0$, and (ii) $f\left(x^{d} + y\right)=x^{3} f(x)+f(f(y))$ for all $x, y$ in $R$.

A55: Mathematics -> Number Theory -> Greatest Common Divisors (GCD)
